Program support to AU peace and security program. Includes mediation, SSR, SALW, salaries, liaison offices and more JFA-stöd för utveckling av AUs freds- och säkerhetsarkitektur APSA. Denna andra fas avser stöd till 85% av avdelningens anställdas löner.

The objectives of the The Joint Financing Arrangement for Support to the Employment of AUC Personnel Working in the Peace and Security Programme (also referred to as the JFA Salaries or "Salary Fund") was to strengthen the capacity of the African Union in the field of peace and security, by supporting staff costs to enable the Peace and Security Department of the AU to hire necessary technical staff. It follows on from a phase one, 2010-2012. Contributing partners have varied over time, and at the outset of the JFA 2013-2017, included European Union (thoughout), Germany, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Netherlands and the UK. The activity period for this contribution was from 2013-06-12 to 2017-12-31, with a total of agreed and disbursed funds, amounting to SEK 54 250 000. The activity period was aligned with the AU Strategic Plan 2013-2017. At the end of 2017, the AU requested an extension of this JFA for an additional year. Following recommendations by Swedish National Auditors Office after contribution review in November 2017, this extension was however assessed in a new contribution (UM2018/03914).

description.narrative: In terms of programme managment, it can be noted that during the period, the financial management team at PSD has been strengthened with additional staff, and that the financial management tool SAP was starting to be rolled out. Also, to be noted that PSD is the only department under the AU Commission with its own finance unit, detached from the finance department. On the project management side, there was an improvement from having a couple of "programme managers" to a programme management team (PMT) being put in place at the very end of the period (end of 2017), with seemingly qualified individuals having worked for i.a. UN or REC:s. The narrative reports, have gone from biannual to annual reports. These have very slowly, but surely, improved in quality over the contribution period although there is still some way to go. Partners continued to raise in Steering Committee meetings, the need to focus on results reporting and move away fomr activity level reporting. During the review of financial reports, the PM/Controller found that the AU Peace and Security Department's (PSD) Finance Unit had submitted financial reports and in addition, narrative financial reports, usually covering a six-month period/financial report. The exception is the period September 1, 2016 - June 30, 2017. The statements show that the Joint fund sometimes (end of 2016, with notably EU not disbursing according to plan) had difficulty in raising the funds/getting disbursements on time from partners compared to their budgets, but that there were means in the fund at the end of this support cycle. The audit reports did not show discrepancies, presumably being based on the final, adjusted books. The below list shows comparison in incoming/Outgoing balances reported in the financial reports.
